Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2011 03:25PM RangerMom wrote: STCC - Had to jump in and say, yes push for that MRI and see what it might tell you. I had a large lump in my right breast and a lymph node on diagnostic ultrasound, then they did an MRI of both breasts and found I had cancer in the left breast too. It got biopsied and came back progestrone positive, the left breast is estrogen positive, 2 different cancers gonig on. The left was Stage 0 and the right was Stage IIIa. So its always good to take a good hard look at both breasts. The good news is I was told only 3-4% of women are diagnosed with simultaneous breast cancer. But whatever, Im glad to know we are getting all the cancer now instead of it coming back to haunt me if I had left the one breast. Also - I did chemo first and the chemo reduced the right breast mass in half but didn't work at all on the left breast. Doesn't matter though since it hadn't metzd and its coming off on Aug 16th anyway and radiation to follow.   I'm like Blondlawyer - can't have reconstruction till 9 mos or so after radiation. I met with the PS yesterday to discuss my options and he is going to mark up my boobs prior to surgery so the BS can save skin for the recon down the road.  Chemo was brutal I have to admit and what helped me through it was not looking too far ahead, but just get me through each day Lord. Also I joined a Chemo group for the month I started and we helped each other out tremendously with side effects (SE) and encouragement. So you might want to jump onto a chemo group too.   Hugs and positive vibes to everyone. Healing prayers to those who have had their surgery already. Love, Linda
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 05:10PM RangerMom wrote: TML, STCC, abatellik, tlaquepaque - My prayers are for you this weekend that you will have a smooth surgery day next Monday and have clear margins and on your way to becoming cancer free! We will have something to celebrate on the other side of this surgery!
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 07:23AM RangerMom wrote: Dogeyed - to answer your questions - I did get my 3 drains out yesterday and last night it was a major improvement in sleeping. Today I'm terribly sore and tingling from my shoulders down my torso. I know its just my nerve endings reacting to all that's gone one. I'll be glad when it all calms down. I am doing pretty good but i do have my moments where i'm so sad and wonder "what's this all for" and what's my purpose here. So I have been on an emotional rollercoaster with ups and downs. I think this in between phase of not being able to do my normal activities, but havaing to be patient for the healing to come, is giving me too much time on my hands to think. I feel unattractive and someone said it earlier, concave, right now and I don't like it. I know I need to be more patient with my body and the job its doing right now to heal.  Welcome to all who joined this week. We are here for you.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 06:57PM RangerMom wrote: Blondlawyer - your energy is low right now and its hard to take any more additional emotional stress and I do believe losin our breasts is a kind of death in its own so having to face reliving your Husband's passing right now is bringing up all the feelings again. Cry hard as you need to and for as long as necessary and you'll take a deep breath when you are done and be stronger afterwards. Also, if you have't tried an icepack at the drain site, that might help too. It helped for me, calmed the area down as I had a stitch that was pulling through my skin and hurt like crazy. Joyce - thank you for the kind words. I know I will find my middle ground soon between these emotional ups and downs and only time will heal this. i've talked to women who are 10 years out from a double mastectomy and are living their best life. I know I will get there too and its like that old saying, its the journey not the destination.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 04:48PM RangerMom wrote: Tlaquepqaue - I still take a Vicodan every once in a while. So take the meds as long as you think its helping, that's why they gave it to us, right!  Today I went to the mastectomy store and got a front closure bra with "fluffies" so when I go back to work I've got a little something to fill out my shirts/dresses. Someone asked if I had reconstruction, and no I can't because I've got radiation coming up next. I have to wait about 9 months after that before I can do anything. Today was a great day, seeing all that's available to help me look normal. I feel much better. It was hard to go by myself so I recommend taking a friend with you for moral support if you can.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 03:24PM RangerMom wrote: My update: double MX on 8/16 with 9 lymph nodes. Chemo done before surgery. On #11 of 33 rad treatments today 10/12. I'll probably stay flat chsted and just go with my prostheses, the thought of more surgery is too much for me. I love my skin the way it is. Hair is growing back and I get lots of compliments. So I have my moments of mourning but they don't last long. Will go on Tamoxifen or the other Armidex soon for 5 years. Love to all, Linda

Posts.Title: Good Scan Results! AmyJM cmhartley

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 04:06AM - edited Apr 14, 2011 04:13AM by RangerMom Hi wolfspring. Wow, seems we have a lot in common but you are a few months ahead of me. I want to do the same as you, chemo first, then surgery, then radiation. I had my pet/ct baseline scan done last week and it shows some irregular nodules in my right lung. I'm waiting to speak with the doc tomorrow. so I understand how you feel so anxious about the test results. Next week is my first visit to the onc.  I will keep you in my prayers. Please keep me posted and I will you on our results. Some things that help me during the wait for all these tests, is watching movies. You can get so engrossed while its on you don't think of anything. Or go to a movie. Being with people does help sometimes as long as I don't get started talking about "stuff."  I went to my local library and picked up several. Reading a good "romance" book helps me too. Silly but anything that keeps my attention away from thinking. Be good to yourself too, maybe a manicure or get out in the beautiful woods for a walk.

Linda

Posts.Content: RangerMom wrote: I'm am in agony over whether or not to talk to my grown children or family whom I'm going to see this week at a family reunion about last week's scans. My CTs showed possible lung lymph node involvement and possible liver lesions. I don't have anything definitive to tell them, as I have a PET if approved (16th) and an MRI of the liver (18th) coming up. These tests are after the reunion. Talking to them would ruin the reunion, or put a damper on it anyway. My parents have lost one daughter to cancer already. I'm even not sure if I do get the dx that there is mets to the liver, if I want to tell them at all. I feel like it would only cause them more alarm, and for what good would it do to upset them more. Initially, with each progression, I would tell them but as time goes on and if its in fact moved to liver and lungs, I'm more hesitant to say anything. I think it would be better to wait for the next treatment to start to take effect and then tell them some good news. I think tonight I'm going to have to take a sleeping pill to knock me out. Anyone have some sage advice for me? thanks so much, linda Extensive mets to spine and both hips. Dx with ca in both breasts, left pr+ and right er+ Dx 3/22/2011, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 3/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 8/15/2011 Lymph node removal: Right, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left, Right Hormonal Therapy 11/30/2011 Aromasin (exemestane) Hormonal Therapy 11/13/2012 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Dx 11/14/2012, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2013 07:18AM RangerMom wrote: too was dx with this in addition to my mbc. I had a tumor of small cell pressing on my spinal canal! It got cut out but grew back even bigger within 2 weeks. Now only carbo is working to shrink the tumor. I get my 2nd round next week. No more xeloda for the mbc mets. Essentially I have 2 different types of cancer fighting in my body, the feast cancer bone mets and the new small cell cancer tumor pressing my spinal canal. I was interested in hearing from those with small cell. My prognosis is less than a yr now. Please send me your thoughts and experiences with small cell if you don't mind and not too painful. I eas told its very aggressive and will be evaluated on me by a chemo by chemo basis. Meaning if chemo fails there is not a go to drug after this. Linda

Posts.Title: They found another suspicious area! BioAdoptMom3 mdg

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2013 03:43PM RangerMom wrote: I can understand your concern. I too had nodules in my right lung (where the worst of the cancer was) and I've had nodules come and go with the docs not concerned.  The one nodule on the PET has stayed the same since since Mar of 2010.  I agree with the advice of Tina, ask more questions till you feel comfortable.  Maybe even ask to have a pulmonary doc take a look at your scans.  I did that and it was very reassuring.  Let us know if you get more info.  Linda
Posts.Title: A question on lung nodules keepingon SyrMom

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2013 04:11PM RangerMom wrote: grand, I haven't been too fortunate with scans being conclusive. I too had pulmonary infiltrate, pneumonia, but after seeing the pulmonary specialist, he wasn't concerned with the nodes.  I even had a chest x-ray done before my double mx that siad I had a nodule that probably should be biopsied but nothing was mentioned to me about it and when I asked was told it was nothing.  I'm learning over the years that there's nothing real cut and dry or black and white with what's going on in our bodies. I've continued to have progression with each scan or MRI so far and in fact am waiting on results from today's scan to see again if there is more or less after more rounds of chemo.  Its like a roller coaster of emotions but in between the tops of the hills of high anxiety, I try hard to find some normalcy (sp?)  Please keep us posted. Linda
Posts.Title: A question on lung nodules keepingon SyrMom

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2013 09:58PM RangerMom wrote: I'vehad rib pain, rt side, now for about 6 months. The bone and CT scans aren't showing any mets though. My BS said it could be pain radiating around from the spine mets (do you have spine involvement too) also said it could be pain from radiation I had 2 years ago even. So who knows. I personally think its mets that just isn't showing up yet. Its very frustrating. They are looking at my liver too for mets right now. I hope for your sake it goes away but I know how it feels. Its hard to not think the worst
Posts.Title: weird pain chris1959 amontro

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2013 08:13AM RangerMom wrote: Chris, just for thought...I took a muscle relaxer this morning instead of vicodan and the muscle relaxer seems to be calming this rib pain down. Do you have any you could try and see for yourself. the pills I had prescribed are called Flexeril 5 mg tablets, 3x per day. I had them prescribed once when I had horrible lumbar pain. They didn't work for that pain and we later found out it was new mets to my hip and S1, L2 that was causing the pain. Its funny how my BS said radiation can cause the pain even after years later. She said my muscles, tissues, etc. are still healing and she said scarring where rads were done. She said to exercise my arms and that would help. Right now exercise is the last thing I want to do. Please post on here what your doc says for you and I hope its not any new mets. Yes, we do drive ourselves crazy each time there is a new pain. Its insane! or we make our loved ones insane!
Posts.Title: weird pain chris1959 amontro

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 04:01PM RangerMom wrote: I too worry about the stats and my SO (significant other) told me "worry more about living than dying" meaning to tell me to quit focusing so much of my time on "is the cancer spreading, is this medicine working" instead to "what do I want to do for fun" and "what makes me happy."  It seems too easy to me to continue to worry and fret over this horrible disease and it takes too much of my energy and I'm not using my energy to live a better life. You know what' i'm saying, especially when you are in the middle of more tests because you've got new bone pain where you didn't have it before, or more tests for whatever......hard to put that in a suitcase and close it
Posts.Title: Expected Life SPAMgirl jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 04:14PM RangerMom wrote: i had 10 sessions to my thoracic spine and only SE I had was mild heartburn but it went away, No burning skin and it helped with pain. a Few months later had 10 rads to my left pelvis/lumbar spine area with no SE and no burning.  It also helped greatly with the pain.  One surprising thing though was the thoracic mets actually grew after rads, not a lot but I had progression.  But it did help with pain.  I would do it again and my RO said he will use radiation again if I need it for new bone met areas or even a way for him to radiate the thoracic area again if needed.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2013 01:59PM RangerMom wrote: Update: got through the family reunion without talking about me. That went well. Had the MRI today and got these results: Numerous cystic foci scattered throughout the liver. There is no clear MRI evidence of enhancement along the periphery and benign cysts would be considered more likely. Question I have: with right rib pain in the front and back ribs and the CT scan saying "enhanced peripheral uptake in liver lesions" would you be content or satisfied with the above impression? I've had this rib pain for about 6 months and its gotten worse in the last couple of weeks. I am going to ask if insurance will cover a PET scan now since the MRI wasn't clear. Do you think a biopsy of one of the cysts (one is 9.5 cm) might be considered too? Or do I just let this go and live with the pain (nothing showed on bone or ct scan in the ribs for mets)???? I am upset that I don't have a clear answer to what is going on. I welcome your opinions again please! Thank you

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2013 06:23PM RangerMom wrote: Not a bad Idea Bobbi. I have family in Bellefontain OH where I sometimes go to visit, but like you, its really hard to be around them and I'm better off when I stay to myself and limit my exposure. That's where I get into a mess and it is a downer for me.

Posts.Title: Scan tomorrow and worried hollander redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2013 04:38AM RangerMom wrote: Hollander, I went off Faslodex (a kind of AI) when there was progression and regression both, and onto Xeloda. The X hasn't been too bad I must say and seems to be keeping the mets to the bone. When the SE;s were really bad, we went to a 7 day on 7 day off and its cut the SE's in half for me. I have seen lots of great results on the Xeloda thread for others and its encouraging. I'm being worked up right now for new spine pain, possible liver involvement, but I actually hope I can continue on the X. I am getting MRIs on Tuesday. Check out the X thread and it might give you some answers you are looking for. Best to you on Monday that you are satisfied with the treatment plan. Linda
Posts.Title: Scan tomorrow and worried hollander redwolf8812

I think often of what might of happend if we had known that earlier would it have made a difference. Answer is probably not. I get sometimes, like this weekend, where I can't stand to be around people. And usually i'm a very socialable person. Most the time, I do what you suggest, but I think its the bone pain and just finishing up the week of xeloda (blistered feet) that has me down.  Being on the board to talk with others is like a life preserve for me.

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 12:16PM RangerMom wrote: Dear Meirav, Hospice can help you find answers to your questions. Or another person who can help is a Nurse Navigator if your Mom has one from the cancer center she goes to? Another option is to call the cancer center social worker and ask for help there. it sounds like you are not satisfied with the treatment your mother is getting and I would think calling and having a dialoge with any of these would start to get you the help you need or get you in the right direction for what to do next. I have to say that there will be a time for all of us that there won't be a treatment left. Its something we learn at the onset of our dx, usually, through our doctors or through literature regarding stage IV mbc. We all hope for a long time before that happens, knowing there will come a time to say we are ready to accept this.  That's where Hospice can help us with the accepting part and the fear of accepting it. Hospice can add to our quality of life even. I am so sorry for you and your Mom going through this very challening time.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2012 08:19AM RangerMom wrote: Hi Everyone, Im also newly diagnosed with mets to the spine, at least that's what we think, but biopsy next week will confirm this. It was caught between CT scans a year apart and showed a spot growing on the T7. Bone scan didn't show any other areas thankfully. I am encouraged that women are living many, many years with bone mets and I hope and plan on being one of them. Thanks for your support. I'll be checking in with you all as I absoluely need you all now. I was very active on here during my chemo, surgery and radiation but dropped off to give myself a break from everything and live normally as I could. Its been a year now since my original dx with bilateral breast ca with nodes. Linda
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 4myangels RangerMom

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 07:18PM RangerMom wrote: Well, I hate to add to confusion here but my T7 bone biopsy, 3 cores also guided by CT, came back as no cancer too. However, 6 mos later, on the bone scan, the T7 had grown and I had a new spot on T9 and my right hip. Needless to say, I DID NOT need it or want it to be biopsied again. I got started on treatments right away on Faslodex and Xgeva. I can't tell you why and my onc couldn't say why either, that the biopsy came back negative.  end result is I got that I needed to be on. See if the onc willdo the same for your mom. I kind of wish we hadn't waited 6 mos to see what was going on. At the time of the biopsy, I knew in my gut that it was cancer. It had been there the previous year on a CT scan but I wasn't told about it and it had grown in a year. hence the biopsy. then grew again and more spots. Hope my story helps
Posts.Title: Can A Bone Biopsy Miss Something? GoldenGirls GoldenGirls

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2013 08:56PM RangerMom wrote: I didn't know where to go to ask my question so I apologize if I've picked the wrong place, please forgive my ignorance. However, try as I might, I can't let go of my crazy thoughts scrambled in my head about my recent MRI. I had a CT scan of the abdomen that suggested mets in my liver via enhanced perhiperhal uptake of lesions. the MRI today said this: A lobular focus is noted anteriorly in the right lobe with some thin internal septation or may correspond to two adjacent cysts or this focus measures up to 2.5 cm. I know it doesn't read right but this is what it said. In the impression it said that the multiple cystic foci were more likely benign because it didn't show any perhiperhal enhancement. So basically, the MRI canceled out what the CT scan said. But....I have horrible right rib pain, front and back ribs and its been on going for 6 months now. Nothing shows in the bones there. What would you do with 2 scans, one saying possible mets and the other not when there is still severe pain? Thanks for your input and thoughts?

Posts.Title: So there I was...... dbla RangerMom

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2013 07:16PM - edited Oct 26, 2013 07:16PM by RangerMom I'm on a break right now from Xeloda and I can tell you I do feel so much better. It was kicking my butt. My HFS is almost gone, my energy is back, and I too have less of that poisoned feeling now. I am loving it. Unfortunately, my spine mets are causing me so much pain I'm needing IV drips of morphine to get by and am in a work up to see if radiation again is necessary. MRI's this Tues of the spine. But in the meantime, the break was/is scarry but I have faith that soon I'll be back on some kind of kick-ass treatment and will be okay! I think a short break has its merits and is worth it. Linda
Posts.Title: Chemo break bhd1 sueco

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2013 11:06PM RangerMom wrote: Thanks for doing this and sharing with us. It was so informative.
Posts.Title: My MBC Article in the Tribune Bestbird Linda-n3

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 10:31AM RangerMom wrote: I'm one of those whose AIs didn't work for me and I had progression while on my initial chemo therapy.  Another type of AI that we tried was Faslodex which is more of a targeted estrogen blocker, that might be good to ask about. It didn't work for me but I've seen others with good results. We did that with Xgeva for the bones similar to Zometa.  Now I'm on Xeloda and after 8 rounds will find out next week if I'm stable or not.  I can definitely recommend Xeloda, the SE's are manageable and my onc says this drug allows her some wiggle room to tweak the dosage to keep the SEs tolerable. Its great having an oral as I can go visit family out of town and take my pills with me. Please keep us posted and wishing you a treatment plan that works for you. It will greatly ease your mind once you are on a plan, I know it did for me.
Posts.Title: Need help making a decision ckachoo ckachoo

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 10:37AM RangerMom wrote: Ckachoo, Yes, its the hardest time is waiting for your treatment plan (or waiting on scans). Once you get a plan, its like "full steam ahead" and it gives you lots of hope and encouragement. Even when I found one wasn't working, its okay...done with that one, let's get going on the next one. My onc says there are hundreds of chemos she can choose from and that gives me much hope that there will continue to be something else to try.   I too want to be around for a long, long time. I have a my first grandbaby due Nov. 3 that I want to give lots of love to!
Posts.Title: Need help making a decision ckachoo ckachoo

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 05:13PM RangerMom wrote: Yes, I sure do. At night it seems to be the worst. I did 10 rad treatments to my mid thoracic area and 10 to my left hip/lumbar area. They did help with the pain. So if you are considering that, it was very easy to do just 10 each time.  I take a vicodan at night for pain and during the day sometimes a half a pill.  There is another thread for just bone mets that I'm on also. Its nice to talk to the other ladies on there. Everyone is very caring. I do the meditation too and food also as medicine. Also do meridian tapping, or called EFT.  That helps with the pain too.  I've learned over the past year that no matter what, no matter how low i feel some days, that I will be okay. Its my mantra....I will be okay.
Posts.Title: Need help making a decision ckachoo ckachoo

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2013 08:35PM RangerMom wrote: So sorry to hear of her side effects.  When I was on the worst chemo, the only thing that helped my nausea and vomiting was Emend. I was told it was one of the strongest things they could give me. I couldn't hold anything down before that, had to IV hydrate me. Ask if that's a possiblity for her.  Another drug is called Aloxi, says it can provided extended relief in both acute and delayed nausea.  Sending you positive thoughts to you and your wife for improved state of being Linda
Posts.Title: From ER/PR+ to Triple Negative sfhusb Latte

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2013 05:40AM RangerMom wrote: Allison, you've come to the right place. When I was first dx with stage IV, thought I was a gonner. I've learned from this group that that is just not true. There are women on here who are NED, Stable and all other situations. But the best thing I've learned from here is to have hope. I get so much encouragement from others here and learn from them. There is a great Bone Mets thread, there more than likely will be a Chemo thread for the type of chemo you will be on and that will give you lots of tips. Linda
Posts.Title: New Here Freedomchild82 AmyJM

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 04:15PM RangerMom wrote: Dear Gina, I'm newly dx this Nov and agree with all said here to you. Once I started on the boards again, it really did give me some calmness in the midst of tests, rad onc appts, etc. This is the hardest time right now and they all told me, it will get better, you'll feel better once your tx start and by God they were right. it's still sinking in but at least now I have hope that i can and I will live a little longer. Where as at first, I could only think, "i wonder when I'm going to die, I wonder how much time I've got left."  I'm more grounded now and calmer. We are all here for you.
